Wine <FI>is<Fi> a mocker, strong drink <FI>is<Fi> raging: and whosoever is deceived thereby is not wise.<CM>
The fear of a king <FI>is<Fi> as the roaring of a lion: <FI>whoso<Fi> provoketh him to anger sinneth <FI>against<Fi> his own soul.<CM>
<FI>It is<Fi> an honour for a man to cease from strife: but every fool will be meddling.<CM>
The sluggard will not plow by reason of the cold; <FI>therefore<Fi> shall he beg in harvest, and <FI>have<Fi> nothing.<RF>cold: or, winter<Rf><CM>
Counsel in the heart of man <FI>is like<Fi> deep water; but a man of understanding will draw it out.<CM>
Most men will proclaim every one his own goodness: but a faithful man who can find?<RF>goodness: or, bounty<Rf><CM>
The just <FI>man<Fi> walketh in his integrity: his children <FI>are<Fi> blessed after him.<CM>
A king that sitteth in the throne of judgment scattereth away all evil with his eyes.<CM>
Who can say, I have made my heart clean, I am pure from my sin?<CM>

Divers weights, <FI>and<Fi> divers measures, both of them <FI>are<Fi> alike abomination to the LORD.<RF>Divers weights: Heb. A stone and a stone<Rf><RF>divers measures: Heb. an ephah and an ephah<Rf><CM>
Even a child is known by his doings, whether his work <FI>be<Fi> pure, and whether <FI>it be<Fi> right.<CM>
The hearing ear, and the seeing eye, the LORD hath made even both of them.<CM>
Love not sleep, lest thou come to poverty; open thine eyes, <FI>and<Fi> thou shalt be satisfied with bread.<CM>
<FI>It is<Fi> naught, <FI>it is<Fi> naught, saith the buyer: but when he is gone his way, then he boasteth.<CM>
There is gold, and a multitude of rubies: but the lips of knowledge <FI>are<Fi> a precious jewel.<CM>
Take his garment that is surety <FI>for<Fi> a stranger: and take a pledge of him for a strange woman.<CM>
Bread of deceit <FI>is<Fi> sweet to a man; but afterwards his mouth shall be filled with gravel.<RF>deceit: Heb. lying, or, falsehood<Rf><CM>
<FI>Every<Fi> purpose is established by counsel: and with good advice make war.<CM>
He that goeth about <FI>as<Fi> a talebearer revealeth secrets: therefore meddle not with him that flattereth with his lips.<RF>flattereth: or, enticeth<Rf><CM>
Whoso curseth his father or his mother, his lamp shall be put out in obscure darkness.<RF>lamp: or, candle<Rf><CM>
An inheritance <FI>may be<Fi> gotten hastily at the beginning; but the end thereof shall not be blessed.<CM>
Say not thou, I will recompense evil; <FI>but<Fi> wait on the LORD, and he shall save thee.<CM>
Divers weights <FI>are<Fi> an abomination unto the LORD; and a false balance <FI>is<Fi> not good.<RF>a false…: Heb. balance of deceit<Rf><CM>
Man's goings <FI>are<Fi> of the LORD; how can a man then understand his own way?<CM>
<FI>It is<Fi> a snare to the man <FI>who<Fi> devoureth <FI>that which is<Fi> holy, and after vows to make enquiry.<CM>
A wise king scattereth the wicked, and bringeth the wheel over them.<CM>
The spirit of man <FI>is<Fi> the candle of the LORD, searching all the inward parts of the belly.<RF>candle: or, lamp<Rf><CM>
Mercy and truth preserve the king: and his throne is upholden by mercy.<CM>
The glory of young men <FI>is<Fi> their strength: and the beauty of old men <FI>is<Fi> the gray head.<CM>
The blueness of a wound cleanseth away evil: so <FI>do<Fi> stripes the inward parts of the belly.<RF>cleanseth…: Heb. is a purging medicine against<Rf><CM>
